Composed by the Sage NÄgÃ¢rjuna
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master KumÄrajÄ«va of Kucha in the Later Qin Dynastyã€SÅ«traã€‘ SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

If good sons and good women uphold this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, associate with it, and contemplate it correctly, they will never suffer from eye, ear, nose, tongue, or body ailments, their bodies will not be mutilated, they will not age prematurely, and will never die an untimely death.
Countless hundreds of thousands of myriads of heavenly beings, from the Four Heavenly Kings up to the Pure Abode Heavens, all follow and listen to it.
On the six monthly observance days - the eighth, twenty-third, fourteenth, twenty-ninth, fifteenth, and thirtieth days, the heavenly assemblies gather.
Good sons who are Dharma teachers all gather where prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is being taught.
These good men and good women, in the midst of the great assembly, expound this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and attain immeasurable, boundless, incalculable, inconceivable, and unfathomable merit and virtue.
The Buddha told SubhÅ«ti:
So it is!
So it is!

These good men and good women, on the six monthly observance days - the eighth, twenty-third, fourteenth, twenty-ninth, fifteenth, and thirtieth days, in the presence of the heavenly multitudes, expound this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. These good men and good women attain immeasurable, boundless, incalculable, inconceivable, and unfathomable merit and virtue.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is a great precious treasure.
What is the great precious treasure?

This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ can pull out beings from the hells, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, and poverty among humans, and can bestow upon them the status of ká¹£atriya, brÄhman, great clan, and wealthy householders, and can bestow upon them the realms of the four heavenly kings up to the realm of neither perception nor non-perception, and can bestow upon them the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, arhatship, pratyekabuddhahood, and supreme perfect enlightenment.
Why is it so?

This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ extensively explains the ten wholesome courses of action, the four concentrations, the four immeasurable minds, the four formless concentrations, the four establishments of mindfulness up to the eightfold noble path, the perfection of giving, the perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of diligence, the perfection of concentration, the perfection of wisdom, and extensively explains inner emptiness up to the emptiness of non-apprehension of non-existent things, and extensively explains the ten powers of the Buddha up to omniscience.
Studying from this, they give rise to the great clans of ká¹£atriyas, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and householders,
and to the heavens of the four heavenly kings, the thirty-three heavens, the yÄma heavens, the
tuá¹£ita heavens, the heavens of enjoyment of emanations, the heavens of control of others' emanations, the brahmÄ heavens, the heavens of brahmÄ's assistants,

the heavens of brahmÄ's retinue, the great brahmÄ heavens, the heavens of limited radiance, the heavens of vast radiance, theğŸ”½heavens of immeasurable radiance, the heavens of streaming radiance, the heavens of limited purity, the heavens of vast purity, the
heavens of immeasurable purity, the heavens of universal purity, the heavens of no-thought, the heavens of good vision, the heavens of excellent vision, and the

highest heavens, the heavens of the base of infinite space, the heavens of the base of infinite consciousness, the heavens of the base of nothingness, and the heavens of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

Those who study this Dharma attain the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, the fruit of arhatship, attain the path of pratyekabuddha, and attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, SubhÅ«ti,
prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is called the great precious treasure.
In the precious treasure pÄramitÄ, there is no dharma that can be attained, whether arising or ceasing, defiled or pure, taken or abandoned;
the precious treasure pÄramitÄ also has no dharma, whether wholesome or unwholesome, worldly or supramundane, contaminated or uncontaminated, conditioned or unconditioned.
For this reason, SubhÅ«ti,
this is called the precious treasure pÄramitÄ of non-attainment.
SubhÅ«ti!
This precious treasure pÄramitÄ is not defiled by any dharma.
Why is it so?
Because the defiling dharmas cannot be attained.
SubhÅ«ti!
Therefore, it is called the precious pÄramitÄ of non-attachment.
SubhÅ«ti!

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way, not knowing, not discriminating, not attaining, and not engaging in conceptual proliferation, this is called cultivating prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
He is able to pay homage to the buddhas, going from one buddha land to another buddha land, making offerings, paying respect, venerating, and praising the buddhas;
Wandering through the buddha lands, he matures sentient beings and purifies the buddha lands.
SubhÅ«ti!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ has no power or non-power over dharmas, it neither receives nor gives, it is neither born nor extinguished, neither defiled nor pure, neither increases nor decreases.

This pÄramitÄ is also not past, not future, not present, it does not abandon the desire realm, it does not abide in the desire realm, it does not abandon the form realm, it does not abide in the form realm, it does not abandon the formless realm, it does not abide in the formless realm.

This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not give to the dÄna-pÄramitÄ, nor does it abandon it, it does not give to the Å›Ä«la-pÄramitÄ, nor does it abandon it, it does not give to the ká¹£Änti-pÄramitÄ, nor does it abandon it, it does not give to the vÄ«rya-pÄramitÄ, nor does it abandon it, it does not give to the dhyÄna-pÄramitÄ, nor does it abandon it, it does not give to the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, nor does it abandon it;
it does not give to internal emptiness, nor does it abandon it, up to it does not give to the emptiness of non-existent phenomena, nor does it abandon it;
it does not give to the four establishments of mindfulness, nor does it abandon them, up to it does not give to the eightfold noble path, nor does it abandon it;
it does not give to the ten powers of the Buddha, nor does it abandon them, up to it does not give to the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha, nor does it abandon them;
It does not give the fruit of stream-entry and also does not abandon it, up to it does not give the fruit of arhatship and also does not abandon it;
It does not give the pratyekabuddha path and also does not abandon it, up to it does not give omniscience and also does not abandon it.
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not give the dharmas of an arhat and does not abandon the dharmas of an ordinary person;
It does not give the dharmas of a pratyekabuddha and does not abandon the dharmas of an arhat;
It does not give the dharmas of a buddha and does not abandon the dharmas of a pratyekabuddha.
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ also does not give conditioned dharmas and does not abandon unconditioned dharmas.
Why is it so?

Whether there are buddhas or not, the characteristics of these dharmas always abide and do not change. The characteristics of dharmas, the abiding of dharmas, and the stage of dharmas always abide, not mistaken and not lost.
[Treatise] Question:
If one upholds prajÃ±Ä and correctly contemplates it, there are still many afflictions. How can it be said that one will never suffer from eye diseases, etc.?
Answer:
This matter has already been extensively explained in the chapter on merits and hells above, namely, karma that does not necessarily receive retribution, so there are no afflictions.
Moreover, because one always upholds, correctly contemplates, and practices in accordance with the teachings of prajÃ±Ä, there are no afflictions.
It is like a good medicine that can cure all illnesses;
if it cannot be used properly, it will not cure afflictions, but this is not a fault of the medicine.
It is also like a skilled swordsman who, although he obtains a sharp weapon, cannot handle difficulties, but this is not a fault of the weapon.

The practitioner is like this. Because of heavy offenses from past lives and not practicing in accordance with the teachings in this life, one does not obtain the power of prajÃ±Ä, but this is not a fault of prajÃ±Ä.
Question:
Since prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ exists in the heavens, why do the gods follow impure people on the six monthly observance days seeking to hear prajÃ±Ä?
Answer:
There are scriptures in the heavens that are transmitted by word of mouth, but they are not spoken by the Buddha.
If it were to exist, it would exist in the Heaven of the Thirty-three and the Heaven of Satisfaction.
Why is this?
When the asuras fought with the gods of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, the Buddha instructed Åšakra DevÄnÄm Indra:
You should recite the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ.
In the Heaven of Satisfaction, there is always a bodhisattva who is about to attain Buddhahood teaching the gods, so it is possible that it exists there.

The gods in the form realm have bodies and garments that are light and have no weight, and they always enjoy tranquility and experience the taste of meditative concentration, therefore they should not have sÅ«tras.
The gods are attached to two kinds of pleasures:
the pleasure of desire and the pleasure of concentration, and they are unable to diligently copy and uphold the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ.
The people of JambudvÄ«pa are able to diligently copy, uphold, study, and correctly contemplate it.
As the sÅ«tra says:
The people of JambudvÄ«pa surpass the gods and the people of Uttarakuru in three ways:
First, they can cut off sexual desires; second, they have strong powers of mindfulness; third, they can be diligent and vigorous.
The people of JambudvÄ«pa are able to write, read, recite, and uphold it. For this reason, the devas come down to pay homage to the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ sÅ«tra, or wish to hear it explained.
Again, some say:
If there is a sÅ«tra in the heavens, it comes from afar to make offerings, increasing merit and virtue, and seeking the perfection of wisdom without ever being satisfied.

There are bodhisattvas whom the devas wish to honor and respect the PrajÃ±Ä[pÄramitÄ], so they come down, wishing to cause beings to increase their faith and respect, thinking, The devas themselves come, let alone us!
If practitioners smell a wonderful fragrance or see a light, because of these rare events, they deeply believe and delight in the PrajÃ±Ä[pÄramitÄ].
Moreover, for those who have not yet escaped desire, evil ghosts and demons always follow, seeking an opportunity to cause them to fall into evil states;
From the Four Heavenly Kings up to the Pure Abode Heavens, these powerful gods come, and the lesser ghosts avoid them.
The Bodhisattva is able to give rise to a pure and great mind, as explained in the previous chapter, and therefore they come to follow the Dharma teacher.
On the six days of observance, the gods come to observe the minds of people, and on the fifteenth and thirtieth days, they report to the gods.
Furthermore, these six days of observance are evil days that bring misfortune to people;

If there are those who observe the eight precepts, keep the fast, give alms, and listen to the Dharma on these days, then the gods rejoice and the lesser ghosts cannot take advantage of them, benefiting the practitioners.
On these days, the Dharma teacher sits on a high seat and expounds the Dharma. For these various reasons, the gods all come.
The expounder of the Dharma praises the immeasurable, boundless, and unsurpassed Dharma, namely the perfection of wisdom, and also attains immeasurable, boundless merit.
If it is expounded to people, because people have dull faculties and little merit, they attain little merit;
The gods have sharp faculties, abundant blessings and virtues, and superior fields of blessings, so they obtain much merit.
Therefore the Buddha said:
On the days of observance, if one recites prajÃ±Ä in the midst of the gods and the great assembly, one will obtain immeasurable blessings.
Here the Buddha approves what SubhÅ«ti said and further explains the causes and conditions of immeasurable blessings and virtues himself, saying that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the precious pÄramitÄ.
Just as a wish-fulfilling jewel can fulfill the wishes of all people;
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ can fulfill the wishes of all sentient beings, namely, to be free from suffering and attain happiness.
As for being free from suffering, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ can pull sentient beings out of the hells, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, and poverty in the human realm;
As for bestowing happiness, it can bestow the status of a great ká¹£atriya family up to supreme perfect enlightenment.
The causes and conditions of this happiness are the wholesome dharmas extensively explained in prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, namely, the ten wholesome courses of action up to omniscience.
It is like a wish-fulfilling jewel that can produce clothes, food, gold, silver, and so forth, according to one's needs.
PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ is also like this, enabling one to attain the ten wholesome paths up to omniscience, the great family of ká¹£atriyas up to Buddhahood.
For this reason, it is called the precious pÄramitÄ.

Furthermore, as for the precious pÄramitÄ, it is like a person who obtains a wish-fulfilling jewel and then obtains everything they need according to their wishes, but loses it and becomes distressed.
This prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ is unborn and unceasing, always not lost, bringing happiness to sentient beings in every life, and finally enabling them to attain Buddhahood.
It is like a person who obtains a wish-fulfilling jewel and then gives rise to self-importance in their mind and despises others, which becomes a cause for decline.

If a person obtains mundane prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, it is also like this, discriminating, attached to wholesome dharmas and abandoning unwholesome dharmas, giving rise to a conceited mind and despising others, then opening the door to all offenses.

The precious prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, which is beyond the mundane world, does not discriminate between good and bad. This is called the great precious pÄramitÄ, which can benefit sentient beings and ultimately bring them peace.
This precious pÄramitÄ cannot be tainted even by good dharmas, let alone bad dharmas.
As it is said here, One does not even know this, meaning that one does not cognize the characteristics of prajÃ±Ä as explained above, nor does one cognize the cognizer;
One does not grasp characteristics or give rise to attachment, does not discriminate, and does not attain fixed characteristics.
This is called being free from faults, free from attachment to dharmas, and cutting off all idle speculation.

Such a person is able to truly practice the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. Because they pay homage to the Buddha with the Dharma and benefit themselves by attaining the true Dharma, they are able to benefit sentient beings;
Because they are able to free themselves from evil and cause sentient beings to be free from evil, they attain a pure buddha-land.

Using the skillful means of non-attainment, they know that the characteristics of all dharmas are ultimately extinguished, yet they are able to give rise to various wholesome dharmas for the sake of sentient beings.
Because prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is ultimately pure, it has no power and is not powerless;
it is like empty space, which, although it is devoid of dharmas, serves as the basis for the accomplishment of various activities.
Since there is no fixed characteristic of any dharma that can be clung to, it has no power;
yet, having attained the true characteristics of all dharmas, it is unimpeded in all wholesome dharmas, and even in subduing MÄra and attaining Buddhahood, it is not without power.
Not accepting, not giving, not arising, not ceasing, and so forth, up to not abandoning conditioned dharmas, not giving to unconditioned dharmas, are also like this.
Here, the reasons are explained:
Whether there are Buddhas or not, the nature of dharmas always abides in the world.
The nature of dharmas refers to the true characteristics of all dharmas;ğŸ”½the true characteristics of all dharmas are prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
If one seeks the true nature of dharmas using permanence, impermanence, and so forth, it is all mistaken;
If a person enters the Dharma-nature and seeks, then there is no error.
The Dharma-nature is always thus and not lost.

ã€Sutraã€‘ At that time, the heavenly beings stood in the sky, let out a great sound, and joyfully scattered udumbara flowers, padma flowers, kumuda flowers, and pundarika flowers over the Buddha, saying:
We have seen the second turning of the Dharma wheel in Jambudvipa.
Here, immeasurable hundreds of thousands of heavenly beings attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The Buddha told Subhuti:
This Dharma wheel is neither the first turning nor the second turning.
This prajnaparamita does not appear for the sake of turning, nor does it appear for the sake of returning, because of the emptiness of dharmas and the non-existence of dharmas.
Subhuti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How is it that because of the emptiness of non-existent dharmas and existent dharmas, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not turn back or regress?
The Buddha said:
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is empty of the characteristics of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, up to dÄna-pÄramitÄ is empty of the characteristics of dÄna-pÄramitÄ;
Internal emptiness is empty of the characteristics of internal emptiness, up to the emptiness of non-existent dharmas is empty of the characteristics of the emptiness of non-existent dharmas;

The four establishments of mindfulness are empty of the characteristics of the four establishments of mindfulness, up to the eightfold noble path is empty of the characteristics of the eightfold noble path;

The ten powers of the Buddha are empty of the characteristics of the ten powers of the Buddha, up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are empty of the characteristics of the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha;

The fruit of stream-entry is empty of the characteristics of the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning is empty of the characteristics of the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning is empty of the characteristics of the fruit of non-returning, the fruit of arhatship is empty of the characteristics of the fruit of arhatship, the pratyekabuddha's path is empty of the characteristics of the pratyekabuddha's path;
All-inclusive cognition is empty of the characteristics of all-inclusive cognition.
SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-honored One!
The prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas is the great pÄramitÄ.
Why is it so?
Although all dharmas are empty of their own marks, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi through prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, yet there are no dharmas that can be attained.
They turn the Dharma wheel, yet there are no dharmas that can be turned or returned;
In this great prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, there are also no dharmas that can be seen.
Why is it so?
Because these dharmas cannot be attained, whether turning or returning, because all dharmas are ultimately unborn.
Why is it so?
Because this mark of emptiness cannot turn or return, the mark of signlessness cannot turn or return, and the mark of wishlessness cannot turn or return.

If one can teach, illuminate, reveal, explain, clarify, and interpret the perfection of wisdom in this way, making it easy to understand, and if there is one who can teach in this way, this is called the pure teaching of the perfection of wisdom.
There is no one who teaches, no one who receives, and no one who realizes;
If there is no teaching, no receiving, no realization, and no extinction, then in this teaching of the Dharma there is also no definite field of blessings.
The Treatise says:
The gods, hearing the prajÃ±Ä, greatly rejoice and leap for joy.
The bodies of the gods are light and their faculties are sharp. They discriminate and cling to characteristics, knowing what is light and heavy;
Hearing that the perfection of wisdom is ultimately pure, the true reality of equality, greatly benefiting beings without any fault, they therefore leap for joy.
They manifest physical and verbal actions, holding offerings such as lotus flowers, making offerings to the Buddha, and say:
We have seen the second turning of the Dharma wheel in JambudvÄ«pa.
Question:
The initial teaching of the Dharma that enables people to attain the Way is called the turning of the Dharma wheel. Why is it now said to be the second turning of the Dharma wheel?
If the Buddha's teachings are called the turning of the Dharma wheel, they are all the Dharma wheel. Why limit it to the second?
Answer:
The initial teaching of the Dharma is called the definitive and true single Dharma wheel. From the initial turning until the end of the Dharma, it is generally called the turning.
These gods see that in this assembly many people have given rise to the unsurpassed Way and attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas;
Seeing this benefit, they praise it as the second turning of the Dharma wheel.
In the initial turning of the Dharma wheel, 80,000 gods attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, and AjÃ±Ätakauá¹‡á¸inya alone attained the initial path;
Now, immeasurable gods have attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas. Therefore, it is said to be the second turning of the Dharma wheel.
The current turning of the Dharma wheel resembles the initial turning.
Question:
Now, when turning the Dharma wheel, many people attain the Way. When turning the Dharma wheel for the first time, few attain the Way. How can you compare the great to the small?
Answer:
The affairs of the Buddhas are of two kinds:
First, secret; second, manifest.
When turning the Dharma wheel for the first time, Å›rÄvaka disciples see eighty thousand [attaining the Way] and one person attains the initial stage of the Way;

The bodhisattvas saw countless asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of people attain the path of the Å›rÄvakas, countless people plant the causes and conditions for the path of the pratyekabuddhas, countless asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of people give rise to the aspiration for the unsurpassed path, countless asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of people practice the path of the six perfections, attain the profound samÄdhis and dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gates, immeasurable sentient beings in the ten directions attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of sentient beings abide from the first ground up to the tenth ground, immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of sentient beings attain the stage of one birth before enlightenment, immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of sentient beings attain the stage of sitting at the site of enlightenment, and hear this Dharma and quickly accomplish the path of buddhahood - such inconceivable characteristics are called the characteristics of the secret turning of the wheel of Dharma.
It is like a great rain, which the large trees receive much and the small trees receive little.
For this reason, one should know that the initial turning of the wheel of Dharma is also great, and there is no fault in using the later to illustrate the former.

The turning of the Dharma wheel is neither one nor two means that it is for the sake of ultimate emptiness and the turning of the Dharma wheel's karmic result, nirvana. This is speaking of the result within the cause.
The Dharma wheel is precisely prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the characteristic of non-arising and non-action, therefore there is no turning and no returning.
It is as explained in the twelve links of dependent arising:
Because ignorance is ultimately empty, it cannot truly give rise to the various activities, etc.;
Because ignorance is false, inverted, and lacks true definiteness, there is no dharma that can be extinguished.
Speaking of the arising of worldly dharmas is called turning;
Speaking of the cessation of worldly dharmas is called returning.
In prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, these two things do not exist, therefore it is said there is no turning and no returning.
Because of the emptiness of non-existent dharmas and existent dharmas - the absence of turning is the emptiness of existent dharmas, the absence of returning is the emptiness of non-existent dharmas.
Question:
Why did Subhuti ask, Because of the emptiness of existing dharmas and non-existing dharmas, prajnaparamita does not turn or return, and therefore appears?
And yet the Buddha still answered with emptiness?
The answer is:
Some say:
All dharmas have four aspects:
1. Existence, 2. Non-existence, 3. Both existence and non-existence, 4. Neither existence nor non-existence.
Among them, due to wrong mindfulness, there are four kinds of wrong practices. Because of attachment to these four dharmas, it is called the wrong path.
Among them, due to right mindfulness, there are four kinds of right practices. Because of non-attachment in the middle, it is called the right path.
Among them, because of refuting neither existence nor non-existence, it is called the emptiness of non-existing dharmas and existing dharmas.
The Buddha says that up to refuting neither existence nor non-existence, therefore it is said there is no turning and no returning.
Refuting neither existence nor non-existence is of two kinds:
First, using the above three sentences to refute, second, using the true nature of nirvana to refute.

Although Subhuti knows that the Buddha uses nirvana to refute existence and nonexistence, there may be newly initiated bodhisattvas who make mistakes, so he uses the three sentences to refute neither existence nor nonexistence, and within the emptiness of dharmas and non-dharmas, they give rise to wrong views again;
Therefore, the Buddha says that existent dharmas and non-existent dharmas are also empty of their own characteristics, and therefore he speaks of prajnaparamita having no turning back.
Within prajnaparamita, there is no characteristic of prajnaparamita, because all dharmas are without characteristics;
Up to dana paramita, it is also like this.
The characteristics of inner emptiness up to the knowledge of all modes are empty, and it is also like this.
At that time, Subhuti and the great assembly joyfully praised prajnaparamita and said:
The great paramita is called prajnaparamita.
As for the great perfection, it means that although all dharmas are empty of inherent nature, prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ can benefit bodhisattvas and enable them to attain supreme perfect enlightenment;
although attained, there is also nothing attained;
although turning the wheel of the Dharma, there is also nothing turned.
Question:
If all dharmas are empty, prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ is empty, and supreme perfect enlightenment is also empty, one should not praise prajÃ±Ä as the great perfection.
Answer:

Here it is said that all dharmas are empty of inherent nature, and within the emptiness of inherent nature, there is also no emptiness of inherent nature. Therefore, it is called the great perfection.
If there were no characteristic of emptiness, one should not raise objections.
Because of ultimate emptiness, there is no obstruction, and one is able to practice all wholesome dharmas and attain supreme perfect enlightenment;
it is due to conventional truth, not ultimate truth.
Although the buddhas expound the Dharma, enabling others to attain the Way and destroy afflictions, going from here to there is called turning.
Now our afflictions are false, inverted, and deceptive, without any fixed characteristics;
if there are no fixed characteristics, what is there to eliminate?
If there is nothing to eliminate, there is also no turning and no returning, therefore it is said although the Dharma wheel is turned, there is also no turning and no returning.
Why is this?
In this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, there is no dharma that can be seen by the five eyes, whether turning or returning, because all dharmas from the very beginning are ultimately unborn.
This is the emptiness of inherent nature, the emptiness of the ultimate, which is neither the characteristic of turning nor the characteristic of returning.
Fearing falling into permanence, one does not turn; fearing falling into annihilation, one does not return;
fearing falling into existence, one does not turn; fearing falling into nonexistence, one does not return;
fearing attachment to the world, one does not turn; fearing attachment to nirvÄá¹‡a, one does not return.
Such self-nature emptiness, ultimate emptiness, the eighteen kinds of emptiness, and immeasurable emptinesses are the door of liberation through emptiness, not turning back;
Signlessness and wishlessness are also like this.
Entering these three doors of liberation, abandoning the mind of I and mine, this is called attaining liberation.
One who is able to not grasp characteristics and not be attached in this way, expounds prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, teaches, illuminates, and so forth.
Expounds means either according with the text or orally transmitting it.
Teaches means praising prajÃ±Ä for others, causing them to accept, uphold, recite, and correctly contemplate it.
Illuminates means like a person holding a lamp to illuminate objects;
If a person does not understand prajÃ±Ä, one illuminates it with the light of wisdom so that they may understand it.
Opens means like a treasure trove with closed doors, although there are fine objects, one is unable to obtain them;
If the doors are opened, then one can take them as one wishes.
It is like a person who doubts and does not believe in prajÃ±Ä. Opening the door of wrong views and breaking through the barrier of ignorance, this person will then be able to take it as they wish.
To show means it is like a person whose eyes are unclear, pointing out what is good or bad;
it is like a person who has a little faith and little wisdom, showing what is the path and what is not the path, what is beneficial and what is harmful, and so forth.
To distinguish means to distinguish various dharmas, what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, what is a sin and what is a blessing, what is the world and what is nirvÄá¹‡a.
The scriptures are concise and difficult to understand and believe in;

one is able to extensively distinguish and explain them, causing one to attain faith and understanding.ğŸ”½To reveal means the Buddha teaches various dharmas to various beings, sometimes disparaging wholesome dharmas and assisting unwholesome dharmas, leading beings to attain understanding.
To expound the Dharma means to expound the Buddha's intentions in accordance with beings, causing them to know the characteristics of what is light and heavy.
Explanation means that just as treasures in a bag are unknown to people when the mouth is tied,
if one explains the contents of the sutra bag for people, explaining the principles.
Moreover, it is like heavy objects, which are unraveled to make them light;
using various causes and conditions and parables, explaining the beginning and end to make it easy to understand.
Shallow and easy means that just as deep water is difficult to cross, if someone divides this water to make it shallow, then those who cross it all find it easy;

prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is like water that is extremely deep, but through the power of skillful explanations, it can be explained in various ways to make it shallow and easy, so that even people with little wisdom can all believe and understand it.
Being able to use these ten as the foremost to explain the profound meaning is called the pure explanation of the meaning of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

In the ultimate truth, there is truly nothing to be said, because of ultimate emptiness. No speaking means no one to receive it. No receiving means no one to realize it. No realization means no one to extinguish afflictions. If there is no one to extinguish afflictions, then there is no one to be a field of blessings.
Receiving means to believe, accept, read, and recite.
Practicing this Dharma, one attains the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a and the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, which is called realization.
When realizing, the afflictions are extinguished, and one attains nirvÄá¹‡a with remainder;
Because one attains nirvÄá¹‡a with remainder, one is definitely a field of blessings.

The definite ones are those whose nature is the same as nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, and therefore it is said that there is no definite field of blessings.ğŸ”½Chapter on the Perfections, Scroll 44 of the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra
SÅ«tra: At that time, SubhÅ«ti, the one with wisdom and life, said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The perfection of the boundless is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because space is boundless.
World-Honored One, the pÄramitÄ of equality is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are equal.
World-Honored One, the pÄramitÄ of separation is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because of ultimate emptiness.
World-Honored One, the pÄramitÄ of indestructibility is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are unobtainable.
World-Honored One, the pÄramitÄ of no other shore is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because there is no name and no body.
World-Honored One, the pÄramitÄ of the seed of emptiness is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because the in-breath and out-breath are unobtainable.
World-Honored One,
The perfection of the inexpressible is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because discursive thoughts cannot be attained.
Seventh, the Blessed One!
The perfection of the nameless is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness cannot be attained.
Eighth, the Blessed One!
The perfection of non-departure is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas do not come.
Ninth, the Blessed One!
The perfection of non-transference is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are unassailable.
Tenth, the Blessed One!
The perfection of exhaustion is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are ultimately exhausted.
Eleventh, the Blessed One!
The perfection of non-arising is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are non-extinguishing.
Twelfth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-extinguishing is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are non-arising.
Thirteenth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-action is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because the doer cannot be apprehended.
Fourteenth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-knowing is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because the knower cannot be apprehended.
Fifteenth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-arrival is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:

Sixteenth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-loss is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:

[Treatise] says:
Boundless pÄramitÄ means that SubhÅ«ti heard the Buddha explain the meaning of the great precious pÄramitÄ, and thus praised prajÃ±Ä as the mahÄpÄramitÄ;
Moreover, with profound wisdom he deeply entered various Dharma gates, and contemplated prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ as being like the boundless ocean water;
Deeply understanding the merits of prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, he gave rise to great joy;
He wished to praise prajÃ±Ä with various causes and conditions, and thus addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The boundless pÄramitÄ is prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ.
The meaning of boundless is from the beginning to the end of the chapter, all of which is the meaning of boundlessness;
It obstructs the explanation of other matters, so it is explained briefly. If explained extensively, it would be immeasurable.

Furthermore, permanence is one extreme, impermanence is one extreme, self and non-self, existence and non-existence, the world having an end and not having an end, sentient beings having an end and not having an end, and so forth, are called extreme views;
Attaining prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, there are none of these extremes, and therefore it is said to be boundless.
Furthermore, it is like the place where things end being called an extreme. Space is formless and shapeless, and therefore it is boundless.
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is ultimately pure, and therefore it has no bounds, no end, no place to grasp, and no place to receive;
This is why the Buddha answers:
Because space is boundless, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is also boundless.

Bodhisattvas attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas and contemplate all dharmas as equal. Therefore, it is said that all dharmas are equal, and therefore it is called the pÄramitÄ of equality.
Bodhisattvas use the mind of ultimate emptiness to be free from all afflictions and also free from all dharmas, therefore it is called the perfection of freedom.
Bodhisattvas use this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ to seek all dharmas in their general and specific characteristics, but do not attain any definite characteristic even as small as a hair.
Because they cannot be attained, their minds are not attached to any dharmas.

If there are people with wrong views and idle speculation who use their minds attached to wrong views to try to destroy these bodhisattvas, because these bodhisattvas have nothing to which they are attached, they cannot be destroyed. This is called the perfection of indestructibility.
This shore is called birth and death, the other shore is called nirvÄá¹‡a, and in between are the great rivers of all afflictions.

All those who leave the home life wish to abandon this shore and become attached to the other shore;ğŸ”½but prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ has no other shore. The other shore is nirvÄá¹‡a, which has no form and no name. Therefore it is said:
Because it has no form and no name, it is called the perfection of no other shore.
If there is space, then there is inhalation and exhalation. Inhalation and exhalation all arise from false and deceptive karmic causes and conditions.
Exhalation is not inhalation, and inhalation is not exhalation. Moment by moment, they arise and cease, and their true nature cannot be obtained.
Because the breath cannot be obtained, all dharmas also cannot be obtained.
Because they cannot be obtained, it is called the perfection of the empty nature.
Because all dharmas are characterized by emptiness and quiescence, they do not need to be contemplated.
Because there is no contemplation, there is no speech.
Because there is no speech, it is said that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ severs the path of language. Therefore, it is called the perfection of the inexpressible.
Two dharmas encompass all dharmas, namely name and form.
The four great elements and the form derived from them are categorized as form.
The four aggregates beginning with feeling are categorized as name.
Those who analyze the various dharmas say:
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is characterized by wisdom, and therefore it is categorized as name.

Now, in reality, it is not apart from form as the name, and not apart from the name as form. This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is characterized by non-knowing, therefore it is said that feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness cannot be obtained, and therefore it is called the nameless pÄramitÄ.
Because all dharmas have no coming and no going, it is called the non-going pÄramitÄ.

PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the treasury of the Dharma of the Buddhas of the three times and the ten directions. It is sealed with the three Dharma seals. No god or human can break it, therefore it is called the unmoving pÄramitÄ.
All conditioned dharmas are exhausted and extinguished moment by moment, and there is no time of abiding.
If that is so, past dharmas are not exhausted, and future dharmas are also not exhausted. Present dharmas do not abide and therefore are not exhausted;
The exhaustion of the three times cannot be obtained, therefore it is called ultimate exhaustion;
Because of ultimate exhaustion, it is called the exhaustion pÄramitÄ.
Because the arising of all dharmas in the three times cannot be apprehended, there is no arising. Because there is no arising, it is called the perfection of non-arising.
The perfection of non-cessation is also like this.
There are two kinds of activity:
First, the activity of sentient beings; second, the activity of dharmas.
The activity of sentient beings refers to giving, upholding precepts, and so forth;
The activity of dharmas refers to being burned by fire, dissolved by water, and what is known by the mind and consciousness.
Because sentient beings are empty, there is no doer;
Because all dharmas are dull and do not give rise to the characteristics of activity, dharmas also do not act.
Because these two are without activity, it is called the perfection of non-action.
The perfection of non-knowing is also like this. Because all dharmas are dull, there is nothing to be known.
The heavenly eye sees there is birth and death. Using the wisdom eye of emptiness, birth and death cannot be apprehended;

Because birth and death cannot be obtained, the death of the aggregates in this world does not lead to the next world. It is only due to the continuity of the causes and conditions of the previous karma of the five aggregates that it is called the perfection of non-arrival.
The perfection of prajÃ±Ä does not lose the true nature of dharmas, and it can also cause all dharmas not to lose their true nature.
Apart from the perfection of prajÃ±Ä, all dharmas are lost.
Contemplating the true nature of all dharmas and attaining the perfection of prajÃ±Ä, therefore it is called the perfection of non-loss.
[Sutra] World-Honored One!
The perfection of dreams is the perfection of prajÃ±Ä.
The Buddha said:
Because even the things seen in dreams cannot be obtained.

The perfection of non-purification is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

Twenty-sixth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-thought is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

Because all thoughts are destroyed.
Twenty-seventh, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-movement is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because the nature of dharmas abides permanently.
Twenty-eighth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-defilement is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are known to be false understanding.
Twenty-ninth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of non-arising is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are non-discriminating.
Thirtieth, World-Honored One!
The perfection of quiescence is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

Thirty-one, World-Honored One!
The pÄramitÄ of no desire is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

the pÄramitÄ of severing is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:

World-Honored One,
the pÄramitÄ of non-duality is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

World-Honored One,
the pÄramitÄ of non-destruction is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

World-Honored One,
the pÄramitÄ of non-grasping is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because it transcends the stage of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
World-Honored One,
the pÄramitÄ of non-discrimination is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:

World-Honored One,
The immeasurable pÄramitÄ is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

The forty-second [question]: World-Honored One!
The space pÄramitÄ is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are non-existent.
The forty-third [question]:
The commentary says:
SubhÅ«ti praises prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, showing that the emptiness of the world of sentient beings is like a dream.
The Buddha said:
Because even the dream cannot be obtained, it is called the pÄramitÄ of dreams.
Echoes, shadows, flames, and illusions are also like this.
The human mind takes sound as real and echo as false;
Shadows take the human face and mirror as real, and the reflection as false;
Flames take wind, dust, and sunlight as real, and water as false;
Illusions take spells as real, and the products of spells as false.
Subhuti praises prajna as empty with metaphors, the Buddha says that both metaphors and actual events are empty;
since actual events are all empty, these metaphors are also empty.
This prajnaparamita is immaculate, able to eliminate all defilements.
The Buddha said:
All afflictions have always been non-existent from the beginning, so what is there to eliminate now?
Therefore, it is called the immaculate perfection.
The undefiled perfection is also like this.
The absence of afflictions is precisely purity.
Lust, anger, and other afflictions are called defilements;
this prajnaparamita is not defiled by any defiled dharmas.

The six sense faculties are the basis of all afflictions. The six sense faculties and all dharmas, the basis and abode of all afflictions, are all unobtainable, and are therefore called the undefiled perfection.
Attaining this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, all frivolous conceptual thoughts are extinguished, thus it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-frivolity.
Because all dharmas are ultimately empty, there are no characteristics of recollection or thought;
Lacking the characteristics of recollection or thought, it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-recollection.
Bodhisattvas abiding in the nature of dharmas cannot be surpassed by any disputers, and cannot be obscured by any afflictions or wrong views;
All dharmas are impermanent and perishable, yet the mind does not give rise to sorrow;
For these causes and conditions, it is called the pÄramitÄ of imperturbability.
Because all dharmas are false understanding, not just tainted by craving, it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-defilement.
Conceptual thoughts are the root of all afflictions;
Having afflictions, one is able to give rise to karmic actions that lead to future rebirths.
Knowing that conceptual thoughts are false, all karmic actions that lead to future rebirths will no longer arise, thus it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-arising.
In prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, the characteristics of the three poisons are not grasped, so it is called the pÄramitÄ of quiescence.
The Buddha said:
Not only are the characteristics of the three poisons extinguished, but the characteristics of all dharmas cannot be obtained.
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not even crave for wholesome dharmas, let alone other desires.
The Buddha said:
Desire, from the very beginning, cannot be obtained.
Craving and desire are false and their intrinsic nature cannot be obtained, so it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-desire;
It is not called non-desire because of being free from desire.
The nature of anger is ultimately non-existent, so it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-hatred;
It is not called non-hatred because of being free from hatred.
In all dharmas, ignorance and darkness are destroyed, so it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-delusion;
It is not called non-delusion because of the extinction of delusion.
As for the perfection of no afflictions, because bodhisattvas attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, all afflictions are extinguished.
The Buddha said:
Conceptual thought and discrimination are the root of afflictions;
since conceptual thought does not exist, how much less so are afflictions!
Therefore it is called the perfection of no afflictions.
PrajÃ±Ä can destroy the mistaken notion of a sentient being within the absence of sentient beings, and is therefore called the perfection of no sentient beings.
The Buddha said:
Since these sentient beings have been originally unborn and non-existent, they are called 'no sentient beings.'
The thought of SubhÅ«ti:
Since prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ can sever all contaminated dharmas, it is called the perfection of severance.
The Buddha said:
Since all dharmas are unarisen and unborn, and have nothing to do with action, all dharmas naturally have the characteristic of severance, and are therefore called severance.

The two extremes refer to self and non-self, annihilation and permanence, dharmas that can be eliminated and dharmas that cannot be eliminated, eternalism and nihilism - such are the innumerable two extremes;
In prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, there are none of these extremes, and thus it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-duality.
The Buddha said:
These extremes have been non-existent from the beginning, but are only clung to due to falsity and inversion;
Bodhisattvas seek the truth and thus depart from these inverted extremes.
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is of one characteristic, empty, and thus cannot be destroyed.
The Buddha said:
Not only is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, all dharmas are without fixed different characteristics.
Cause is not separate from effect, effect is not separate from cause;
Dharmas with characteristics are not separate from dharmas without characteristics, dharmas without characteristics are not separate from dharmas with characteristics;
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is not separate from all dharmas, all dharmas are not separate from prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
The true nature of all dharmas is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, therefore it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-destruction.
Destruction refers to the various dharmas being scattered and dispersed.
All dharmas have faults such as permanence and impermanence;
Therefore, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not grasp at any dharmas.
The Buddha said:
Even the pure dharmas of the two vehicles that transcend the world are not grasped at, therefore it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-grasping.
Distinguishing and labeling gives rise to grasping at characteristics and conceptual thoughts;
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the true nature, therefore it is free from such conceptual thoughts and discriminations.
The Buddha said:
Based on memory and conceptual thoughts, there is discrimination of existence and non-existence;
Now, memory and conceptual thoughts have been non-existent from the very beginning, therefore it is called the pÄramitÄ of non-discrimination.
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ transcends the four immeasurables, therefore it is called the pÄramitÄ of the immeasurable.
Furthermore, ultimate emptiness is called immeasurable because it attains immeasurable dharmas of nirvana.
Furthermore, the limit that cannot be reached by wisdom is called immeasurable.
This is what the six sense faculties can measure;
This dharma is empty, without characteristics, and without arising or ceasing, and cannot be measured by the six sense faculties.
Why is this?
Because the objects are many and the measuring vessel is small.
The Buddha said:
Not only is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ immeasurable, but all dharmas such as form are also immeasurable because they cannot be apprehended.
Just as space has no form, no shape, and nothing it can do;
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is also like this.
The Buddha said:
Not only is space nonexistent, but all dharmas such as form are also nonexistent, and therefore it is called the perfection of space.
[Sutra] World-Honored One!
The perfection of impermanence is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are destroyed.
BhagavÄn!
The pÄramitÄ of suffering is the prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ.

Because all dharmas have the characteristic of affliction.

World-Honored One, the perfection of internal and external emptiness is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because internal and external dharmas cannot be obtained.
World-Honored One, the perfection of emptiness of emptiness is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because the dharma of emptiness of emptiness cannot be obtained.
World-Honored One, the perfection of great emptiness is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas cannot be obtained.
World-Honored One, the perfection of emptiness of the ultimate truth is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because nirvÄá¹‡a cannot be obtained.
World-Honored One, the perfection of emptiness of conditioned phenomena is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because conditioned dharmas cannot be attained.
Fifty-fifth, the World-Honored One!
The emptiness of the unconditioned is the pÄramitÄ of prajÃ±Ä.
The Buddha said:
Because the unconditioned dharma cannot be attained.
Fifty-sixth, the World-Honored One!
The emptiness of the ultimate is the pÄramitÄ of prajÃ±Ä.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are ultimately unattainable.
Fifty-seventh, the World-Honored One!
The emptiness of beginninglessness is the pÄramitÄ of prajÃ±Ä.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas are beginningless and unattainable.
Fifty-eighth, the World-Honored One!
The emptiness of dispersion is the pÄramitÄ of prajÃ±Ä.
The Buddha said:
Because dispersed dharmas cannot be attained.
Fifty-ninth, the World-Honored One!
The emptiness of nature is the pÄramitÄ of prajÃ±Ä.
The Buddha said:
Because conditioned and unconditioned dharmas cannot be apprehended.
World-Honored One,
the emptiness of all dharmas is the perfection of wisdom.
The Buddha said:
Because all dharmas cannot be apprehended.
World-Honored One,
the emptiness of intrinsic nature is the perfection of wisdom.
The Buddha said:
Because intrinsic nature is detached.
World-Honored One,
the emptiness of non-existent dharmas is the perfection of wisdom.
The Buddha said:
Because non-existent dharmas cannot be apprehended.
World-Honored One,
the emptiness of existent dharmas is the perfection of wisdom.
The Buddha said:
Because existent dharmas cannot be apprehended.
World-Honored One,
the emptiness of non-existent and existent dharmas is the perfection of wisdom.
The Buddha said:
Because non-existent and existent dharmas cannot be apprehended.
World-Honored One!ğŸ”½
World-Honored One, the perfection of mindfulness is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
Because the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas cannot be obtained.

[Treatise] says:
In the perfection of wisdom, there is the holy practice of impermanence, so it is called the perfection of impermanence.
The Buddha said:
It is not only that impermanence exists within prajÃ±Ä, because all dharmas are contemplated as impermanent, it is called the perfection of impermanence.
Question:
Above it was said that the nature of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is eternally abiding, why is impermanence spoken of now?
Answer:
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is wisdom, contemplating dharmas arising from the combination of causes and conditions, it is a conditioned dharma and therefore impermanent;
The object of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, suchness, dharma-nature, and reality, are unconditioned dharmas and therefore eternal.
SubhÅ«ti speaks of conditioned prajÃ±Ä, therefore he says prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is impermanent.
Question:
If that is so, why did the Buddha say that all dharmas are destroyed and impermanent, and that unconditioned dharmas have the characteristic of indestructibility?
Answer:
All dharmas refer to the six sense faculties, both internal and external are created dharmas;
Because they are created dharmas, they must return to the characteristic of destruction.
Apart from conditioned dharmas, there are no unconditioned dharmas, and there are also no characteristics of dharmas;
Because of the characteristics of conditioned dharmas, it is said that unconditioned dharmas are non-arising and non-ceasing.
Furthermore, all conditioned dharmas are of two kinds:
First, all in terms of names, second, all in terms of reality.
All conditioned dharmas are destroyed, therefore they are called all impermanent.
Suffering and so forth, up to emptiness of existent and non-existent dharmas are also like this.
SubhÅ«ti praises prajÃ±Ä by speaking of the characteristics of all dharmas, the Buddha answers by bringing up all dharmas.

The correct contemplation of the four dharmas of the body and so forth arises from the four establishments of mindfulness. The four establishments of mindfulness are the initial gateway to the four noble truths. The four noble truths are the initial gateway to the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a. The discrimination of the fruit of arhatship is precisely the three vehicles.
The four establishments of mindfulness are extensively explained in various ways within prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
The Buddha said:
These four kinds of dharmas are objects of conditions, and have been unobtainable from the beginning, therefore they are called the pÄramitÄ of mindfulness.
From the four right efforts up to the pÄramitÄ of prajÃ±Ä, it is also like this.
Question:

Answer:
There are two kinds of prajÃ±Ä:
The first is the eternally abiding prajÃ±Ä;
The second is the prajÃ±Ä that is used in conjunction with the five pÄramitÄs, which is the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ that is used.
SubhÅ«ti praises the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ that is used, which can destroy the darkness of ignorance and bestow true wisdom;
Therefore the Buddha says:
The eternally abiding prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, because ignorance and wisdom are unobtainable.

The bodhisattva who practices this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ first attains the ten powers of a bodhisattva, and later attains the ten powers of a buddha. Therefore it is said to be the pÄramitÄ of the ten powers.
The Buddha said:
Not only is the one with the ten powers unbreakable and unvanquishable, the true nature of all dharmas is also unbreakable and unvanquishable.
The Buddha's intention is:
In order to deliver sentient beings, he speaks of the boundless and limitless power of the buddhas in the ten directions;
Just as the power of the buddhas is unvanquishable, the true nature of all dharmas is also like this and cannot be subdued, so it is called the perfection of the ten powers.
The bodhisattva attains the power of this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ and is able to expound the Dharma and engage in discussions in the presence of the Buddha, let alone in other places!
He is not even afraid of the demon king, let alone non-Buddhist paths!
Therefore, it is called the perfection of fearlessness.
The Buddha said:
Because the knowledge of the aspects of the path is not submerged.
The knowledge of the aspects of the path is called the Dharma eye, which knows by what path all sentient beings can attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is always characterized by quiescent extinction and cannot be spoken of;
This bodhisattva, because of the knowledge of the aspects of the path, guides sentient beings and roars the lion's roar in the great assembly;

Because of the increase of the knowledge of the species of the path, one does not sink, and one is fearless. One does not arrogantly think, I have this Dharma, and is called the perfection of fearlessness.
SubhÅ«ti, having heard from the Buddha, the fearlessness deepened, so he praised the perfection of wisdom, saying, The perfection of non-obstruction.
The Buddha said:
Not only the four unobstructed [abilities], but all dharmas enter suchness, the nature of dharmas, and the ultimate reality, therefore they are all the characteristic of non-obstruction.

Because the bodhisattva, due to the perfection of wisdom, is able to gather the ten powers, the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed [abilities], great kindness, great compassion, and other Buddha-dharmas, it is said to be the perfection of the Buddha-dharmas.
The Buddha said:
The Å›rÄvaka Dharma is superior to the dharmas of ordinary people, the pratyekabuddha Dharma is superior to the Å›rÄvaka Dharma, and the Buddha Dharma is the most superior of all dharmas.
Just as space is vast among all forms,
The Buddha's teachings are supreme, unsurpassed, and incomparable. Transcending all dharmas, they are called the perfection of the Buddha's teachings.
Just as the Buddhas of the past practiced the six perfections and attained the true nature of all dharmas,
the present Buddha likewise practiced the six perfections and attained Buddhahood. Therefore, it is called the perfection of the TathÄgata.
TathÄgata is sometimes said to mean thus come or thus speak or thus know.
Here, the Buddha says:
It is not only the Buddha's teachings that are called thus speak. All language is thus speak, and therefore it is called the perfection of thus speak.
This perfection of wisdom is complete, and in the next life one naturally becomes a Buddha. Therefore, it is called the perfection of naturalness.
Naturalness refers to the Buddha;
because it is spoken by the Buddha, it is called the perfection of naturalness.
Furthermore, this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the true nature of things, spontaneously accomplished without relying on others, and is therefore called spontaneous.
The Buddha said:
The Buddha has attained mastery over all dharmas, and is therefore called the spontaneously accomplished one.

Having perfected the ten grounds, attained the ten powers and four fearlessnesses, turned the wheel of Dharma and beaten the Dharma drum, he awakens sentient beings from the slumber of ignorance in the world, and is therefore called the Buddha-pÄramitÄ.
Buddha means the enlightened one, the knowing one, in the Qin language.
Who is it?
It refers to the one who correctly knows all dharmas and all aspects, and is therefore called the enlightened one.
All dharmas refer to the five aggregates, twelve sense fields, eighteen elements, and so forth.
Furthermore, all dharmas refer to the scriptures of non-Buddhists, skills, meditative absorptions, and so forth;
In brief, there are five kinds, namely the dharmas of ordinary beings, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas.
The Buddha, in brief, knows two kinds of characteristics, namely, general characteristics and specific characteristics;
And by means of the characteristics of discrimination and the ultimate emptiness.
If known in detail, it is of all kinds - all kinds are all immeasurable and boundless Dharma gates.
For this reason, it is called the perfection of the Buddha;
